Input paragraph: In cases where automatic retrieval of metadata fails or produces incorrect references --- which is most common for URL citations --- users can manually provide the correct metadata using common reference formats. Manual metadata also supports references without standard identifiers, such as print-only newspaper articles. Table @tbl:citations presents the supported identifiers and example citations before and after Manubot processing. Authors can optionally define citation tags to provide short readable alternatives to the citation identifiers. Citation metadata is exported to the [Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items](http://citeproc-js.readthedocs.io/en/latest/csl-json/markup.html#items) format, an open standard that is widely supported by reference managers [@doi:10.1007/978-3-319-00026-8_8; @doi:10.1080/02763869.2012.641841]. However, sometimes external resources provide Manubot with invalid CSL Data, which can cause errors with downstream citation processors, such as [pandoc-citeproc](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/pandoc-citeproc). Therefore, Manubot removes invalid fields according to the [CSL Data specification](https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema). Manubot includes an additional layer of citation processing, currently unique to the system. All citations point to a standard identifier, for which Manubot automatically retrieves bibliographic metadata such as the title, authors, and publication date.

There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

response.output: Within the broader field of open science, a significant challenge resides in the accurate and reproducible citation of various sources, particularly those without standard identifiers such as URL citations and print-only articles. This manuscript addresses this gap by introducing Manubot, a tool designed to enhance the quality and reliability of metadata retrieval for a wide range of references. This novel approach to citation management not only addresses the current gaps but also advances the field by providing a more reliable and comprehensive citation management system.

Revise the following methods of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure and fits in a single paragraph. The revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance"). If any part of the C-C-C scheme is missing, put an HTML comment in the place where it belongs with its name, so I can fill it in.

Input paragraph: In cases where automatic retrieval of metadata fails or produces incorrect references --- which is most common for URL citations --- users can manually provide the correct metadata using common reference formats. Manual metadata also supports references without standard identifiers, such as print-only newspaper articles. Table @tbl:citations presents the supported identifiers and example citations before and after Manubot processing. Authors can optionally define citation tags to provide short readable alternatives to the citation identifiers. Citation metadata is exported to the [Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items](http://citeproc-js.readthedocs.io/en/latest/csl-json/markup.html#items) format, an open standard that is widely supported by reference managers [@doi:10.1007/978-3-319-00026-8_8; @doi:10.1080/02763869.2012.641841]. However, sometimes external resources provide Manubot with invalid CSL Data, which can cause errors with downstream citation processors, such as [pandoc-citeproc](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/pandoc-citeproc). Therefore, Manubot removes invalid fields according to the [CSL Data specification](https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema). Manubot includes an additional layer of citation processing, currently unique to the system. All citations point to a standard identifier, for which Manubot automatically retrieves bibliographic metadata such as the title, authors, and publication date.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, abstract, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

Within the broader field of open science and collaborative writing, the challenge of accurately and efficiently managing references has remained a persistent issue, particularly when automatic metadata retrieval fails or generates incorrect references, a problem frequently encountered with URL citations. This study introduces Manubot, a novel approach that allows users to manually provide accurate metadata using common reference formats, thereby accommodating references without standard identifiers like print-only newspaper articles. Manubot's capabilities and example citations are demonstrated in Table @tbl:citations. In addition, Manubot enables authors to define citation tags, offering short, readable alternatives to citation identifiers. All citation metadata is exported to the widely supported Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items format. However, issues can arise when external resources supply Manubot with invalid CSL Data, potentially causing errors with downstream citation processors. To address this, Manubot removes invalid fields in accordance with the CSL Data specification and incorporates an additional layer of citation processing unique to the system. Resultantly, all citations point to a standard identifier, with Manubot automatically retrieving key bibliographic metadata such as title, authors, and publication date. This innovative approach to citation management not only enhances the accuracy and efficiency of referencing in collaborative writing but also advances the broader field of open science by promoting reproducibility and provenance.

The field of metadata retrieval, particularly for URL citations, often encounters issues such as failure or incorrect references, necessitating manual input of correct metadata using common reference formats. This gap is especially significant in cases of references lacking standard identifiers, such as print-only newspaper articles. Our research addresses this gap with Manubot, a system that allows users to manually provide correct metadata and supports references without standard identifiers. As shown in Table @tbl:citations, Manubot processes identifiers and citations and offers the option for authors to define citation tags as short, readable alternatives to citation identifiers. The processed citation metadata is then exported to the Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items format, an open standard widely supported by reference managers. However, Manubot sometimes receives invalid CSL Data from external resources, causing errors with downstream citation processors, such as pandoc-citeproc. To counter this, Manubot removes invalid fields as per the CSL Data specification. In a novel approach unique to the system, Manubot adds another layer of citation processing: all citations are linked to a standard identifier, from which Manubot automatically retrieves bibliographic metadata like title, authors, and publication date. The successful implementation of Manubot not only resolves the issue of incorrect or missing metadata but also advances the broader field of metadata retrieval by introducing an additional layer of citation processing.

Within the broader field of digital citation management, automatic retrieval of metadata often fails or produces incorrect references, especially for URL citations. This gap in accurate and efficient citation management poses a challenge for users who need to manually provide the correct metadata using common reference formats, including references without standard identifiers such as print-only newspaper articles. To address this issue, we introduced Manubot, a novel system that supports manual metadata and allows authors to define citation tags for short readable alternatives to citation identifiers. Manubot processes the provided metadata and exports it to the Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items format, a widely supported open standard by reference managers. To prevent this, Manubot removes invalid fields according to the CSL Data specification and includes an additional layer of citation processing, unique to the system, where all citations point to a standard identifier. Manubot then automatically retrieves bibliographic metadata such as the title, authors, and publication date. The widespread issue of incorrect or failed automatic metadata retrieval, particularly for URL citations, presents a significant gap in the field of open collaborative writing. This is especially problematic for references without standard identifiers, such as print-only newspaper articles. To address this gap, we developed a novel approach using Manubot, which allows users to manually provide accurate metadata using common reference formats. Manubot also offers an optional feature where authors can define citation tags to provide more readable alternatives to citation identifiers. All citation data is exported to the widely supported Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items format. However, we found that external resources sometimes supply Manubot with invalid CSL Data, leading to errors with downstream citation processors. In response, we enhanced Manubot's functionality by adding a layer of citation processing that removes invalid fields according to the CSL Data specification. Furthermore, Manubot ensures that all citations point to a standard identifier, automatically retrieving essential bibliographic metadata such as title, authors, and publication date. This unique feature of Manubot not only resolves the specific issue of incorrect metadata retrieval but also advances the broader field of open science by enhancing reproducibility and provenance in collaborative writing.

In the broader context of open collaborative writing, a significant challenge lies in managing and processing citations, particularly when integrating diverse identifier systems and dealing with invalid data. Our manuscript addresses this gap by introducing Manubot, a tool designed to streamline the citation process. As detailed in Table @tbl:citations, Manubot supports various identifiers and provides the option for authors to define citation tags for readability. The tool exports citation metadata to the Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items format, a widely accepted open standard among reference managers. However, Manubot encounters occasional issues with invalid CSL Data from external resources, leading to errors with downstream citation processors such as pandoc-citeproc. To rectify this, Manubot has been designed to remove invalid fields in accordance with the CSL Data specification. This innovative approach to handling citations not only addresses the immediate problem of invalid data but also contributes to the larger goal of improving reproducibility and provenance in open science writing.

In the realm of academic writing, the process of citing references is crucial, yet often cumbersome. Current citation systems often rely on manual input and suffer from inconsistency and errors. Our research addresses this gap by introducing Manubot, a tool designed to simplify and streamline the citation process. Manubot's capabilities are outlined in Table @tbl:citations, which presents the identifiers it supports and examples of citations before and after processing. Authors can define citation tags for a more readable alternative to citation identifiers. Manubot exports citation metadata to the Citation Style Language (CSL) JSON Data Items format, a widely supported open standard by reference managers. However, Manubot sometimes encounters invalid CSL Data from external resources, leading to errors with downstream citation processors like pandoc-citeproc. To mitigate this, Manubot is designed to remove invalid fields in accordance with the CSL Data specification. The introduction of Manubot not only simplifies the citation process but also reduces the potential for errors, thereby enhancing the overall quality of academic writing.
